did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.abstract: Fagan's collection consists primarily of reel to reel tapes (1033). The rest of the materials are music memorabilia, Fagan's own writings and documents concerning the United Nations.
did.langmaterial: Languages represented in the collection: English

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for research. Listening appointments may require 24 hours notice. Contact the Archive Operations Manager.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: Property rights reside with repository. Publication and reproduction rights reside with the creators or their heirs. To obtain permission to publish or reproduce, please contact the Head Librarian of the Archive of Recorded Sound.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Ted Fagan Collection, ARS-0008. Courtesy of the Stanford Archive of Recorded Sound, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, Calif.

bioghist.head: Biography / Administrative History
bioghist.p: Theodore Fagan, of Jewish-English background was born in Buenos Aires, Argentina on Feb. 21, 1921. His early education included five years at a boarding school in England. Back in Argentina he completed a degree in Civil Engineering (1943). Two years later he came to New York, and within months was hired as a United Nations Spanish, French and English interpreter. One of his earlier assignments included the Nuremberg War Trials (1946), and through his thirty-year long involvement with the UN he interpreted speeches from leaders such as Prime Minister Fidel Castro and President L?opold S. Senghor of Senegal. Fagan was an indefatigable writer, his many writings include two historical novels --on Evita Per?n, and on the famous 19th century Parisian lawsuit of La Ronci?re-- a historical drama, Elizabeth Rex, produced in Los Angeles (1963), and his memoirs on his long association with the United Nations. Fagan had a life-long passion for music and collected music memorabilia and recordings. After retiring form his work at the UN, at age 55, he collaborated with William R. Moran on The encyclopedic discography of Victor recordings. Matrix series 1 through 4999: the Victor Talking Machine Company, 24 April 1903 to 7 January 1908, published by Greenwood Press in 1986. Fagan died in New York in 1987.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: Throughout his life and multiple travels associated with his UN work, Ted Fagan collected music memorabilia, and over a thousand reel to reel recordings, which are primarily operatic. Fagan recorded several compilations of selected opera singers, often organized by voice range. Among the reel to reels are the annual UN Human Rights Day concerts and some intriguing tapes such as the contested recordings of Richard Wagner conducting a passage of Act II of Tristan und Isolde, presumably from 1880, and possibly of soprano Jenny Lind singing Ah! non giunge, from Bellini?s Sonnambula, from 1883. Among the music memorabilia are two Medieval manuscripts, a notated missal leaf with musical notation, from about the late 10th and early 11th century and a leaf from the church canon from the 12th or 13th century; a British engraved vocal piece from the 18th century; a letter by Gaspare Spontini from 1847 and a program autographed by Aaron Copland. Among the art works are two engravings depicting Fryderyk Chopin and Marie Falcon, a lithograph of Jenny Lind, and about a dozen etchings by the Spanish artist Vicente Gand?a. The collection also includes over fifty photographs, most of which are autographed, Fagan?s multiple writings, and a large body of documents relating to the United Nations and interpreting.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series Description: 1. Photographs; 2. Art work; 3. Music memorabilia; 4. Programs; 5. Opera notes; 6. Reel to reel tapes; 7. Discs; 8. Cassettes; 9. Video tapes' 10. Fagan's writings.

did.unittitle: Leaf from a Medieval Full Missal
did.physdesc: Vellum, 11" by 8 3/4" ; sepia and red caligraphy

scopecontent.p: Notated missal leaf. Liturgical text in Latin for the procession of the Feast of Purification of the Blessed Virgin Mary, followed by the Introit of the mass. With musical notation, neumes in campo aperto. Probably Old German-Lorraine neumes, but scarcely distinct from the St. Gall notation, dating from about the late 10th and early 11th century.

did.physdesc: Vellum, 16" by 10" ; 2 leaves, 4 pages ; sepia, blue and red caligraphy

scopecontent.p: Latin text in two columns with many abbreviations. Rubrication and initials marking paragraphs are standard and relatively simple. Some of the topics dealt with include, bishops residences, schimates or people who have stepped out of the church, usury and homicide. Probably dating from the 12th or 13th century.
Title page: " Zu Philipp Jarnach. Kurt Weil. Fantasia, Pasacaglia u. Hymnus. op.6."

Two-page piano piece manuscript in pencil. Found together with the Kurt Weil title page (see 3.11). Top of first page "Ein bischen Liebe brauch man doch z. glückl. sein." Bottom second page "Nach Gesangabschluss noch 16 Takten Violin solo (mit Spring[?])" "folgt 9 a"
Some of the main sections are: Gluck, Christoph Willibald, Ritter von, 1714-1787. Alceste (1776) -- Giordano, Umberto, 1867-1948. Andrea Chénier
The main section deals with Bizet, Georges, 1838-1875. Carmen
Some of the main sections deal with castrati and the legend of Faust in music
The main sections deal with Monteverdi, Claudio, 1567-1643. Orfeo and to a lesser extent with Incoronazione di Poppea
The main sections deal with singing in general and Puccini, Giacomo, 1858-1924. Tosca
The main section deals with the opening of the San Francisco Opera

Transcription of the composer's letter included with the tape: Buenos Aires, Dec. 16, 1956 Dear Ted, Aquí le envío el rollo que ud. me dejó. Hace pocos días le envié una carta que espero haya recibido. La partitura de mi "Diptico" aun no se la puedo enviar porque aqui en B.A. hay una huelga prolongada de los gráficos. Esto obstruye el trabajo. Deseo que mis cosas puedan interesar allí. Espero con impaciencia noticias suyas. Un abrazo Valdo
